Authors:
Pieter De Maayer, Wai Yin Chan, Douglas AJ Martin, Jochen
Blom, Stephanus N Venter, Brion Duffy, Don A Cowan, Theo HM Smits,
Teresa A Coutinho
Title:
The Pantoea ananatis integrative conjugative element ICEPan
plays a potential role in its ecological diversification and
antibiosis
Keywords:
Pantoea; ananatis; integrative and conjugative
element
Abstract:
Background: Pantoea ananatis is a highly versatile
enterobacterium which is frequently isolated from diverse environmental
sources. The ecological diversity of this species may be attributed, in
part, to the acquisition of mobile genetic elements. One such element is
the Integrative and Conjugative Element (ICE). Results: By means of in
silico analyses the P. ananatis ICE (ICEPan) was identified and
characterized. PCR screening showed that ICEPan is prevalent among P.
ananatis strains isolated from different environmental sources and
geographic locations. ICEPan shared a common origin with the ICEs of
other enterobacteria, as well as conjugative plasmids of Erwinia spp.
Aside from core modules for the integration, maintenance and
dissemination of ICEPan, these mobile genetic elements contain extensive
non-conserved islands coding for proteins that may contribute towards
various phenotypes such as stress response and antibiosis. An island is
integrated within an ICEPan DNA repair-encoding locus umuDC and we
postulate its role in stress-induced dissemination and/or expression of
the genes on this island. Conclusions: The highly diverse integrative
and conjugative element ICEPan of P. ananatis encodes proteins that may
play a major role in the ecological diversification of this
species.
